title: 111_hr4250
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a concise summary of the section's title and its purpose. The "Medicaid DSH Integrity Act" recognizes the importance of Medicaid DSH payments for safety net hospitals serving low-income individuals. It emphasizes the need for auditing and reporting requirements to ensure proper use of funds. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services issued regulations that narrow the scope of DSH payments for many States, resulting in significant payment reductions to safety net hospitals serving low-income individuals. Congress did not intend to change the definition of DSH-eligible costs or the existing DSH program standards. The policy changes in regulations would lead to significant DSH payment reductions for safety net providers in the Medicaid program. Revision of Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with States and disproportionate share hospitals, will not enforce changes in policy regarding the calculation of limits under the Social Security Act. An interim final rule will be published to revise the Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations as necessary. The interim final rule will correct policy changes related to the calculation of limits under the Social Security Act and provide guidance for implementing Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations. Regulatory changes will allow inclusion of all costs related to services provided to uninsured patients. The interim final rule addresses policy changes regarding the calculation of limits under the Social Security Act and provides guidance for implementing Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations. It allows for the inclusion of all costs related to services provided to uninsured patients, regardless of insurance coverage for other services. States can use their definition of allowable costs in computing such costs as long as they do not exceed Medicare principles of cost reimbursement. The CMS will interpret the audit requirement language to align with the term "hospital services" in the Social Security Act. They will revise the General DSH Audit Protocol to allow for different cost-to-charge ratios and amend regulations to permit alternatives. CMS will revise regulations to allow alternative methodologies for determining actual costs, including trending forward costs from prior years. The Social Security Act will be amended to change the initiation requirements, and definitions for CMS and Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations are provided. The term "Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations" refers to the final regulation issued on December 19, 2008, and published in the Federal Register. The term "Medicaid DSH program" pertains to the program of payment adjustments under section 1923 of the Social Security Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through CMS.
